bibl.title: Letter from M.A. Barber to Henry Rose Carter, May 10, 1923

div1.p: Barber writes about collecting data on types of malarial parasites.

div1.head: Letter from M.A. Barber to Henry Rose Carter, May 10, 1923
div1.opener:
N. M. Cam
Barber
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Crowley, La. May 10, 1923.
My dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
Notes of Chara received. I am very glad to get these.
I am on the lookout for any Characeae, but have seen none as yet.
They appeared in the rice fields of Ark. last summer,
and are likely to be found here.

I am getting some data on seasonal incidence types of malaria parasites.
Over 1800 positives from Dr. Thibault and over 1300 from the Memphis
laboratory. I have worked these two lots out so far as I can.
I will get further data. Interesting thing noted by Dr. Thibault.
is the far higher incidence of B.T. in white cases. 1476 negro positives
gave only 12.6% B.T. while 363 whites gave 67.5% B.T. I have not yet
the Memphis figures by color, but the B.T. curve is very high and the
most of the hospital patients were probably white. The Memphis
B.T., however in October, swoops down to nearly the same low level as that
of the Thibault plantation group. Of course, a ready explanation
of the high B.T. in white patients is that this better treated group
shed their S.T. But why do not they shed it in late summer as well?
Do not bother to answer this letter unless the spirit moves strongly.

At Week's Is. salt marshes yesterday. A. crucians by the hundreds
biting freely in broad daylight, even in the direct sunlight.
